title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The schism within the Republican party deepened on Tuesday after Donald Trump launched a blistering attack on Mitch McConnell, calling the senior Senate Republican a “dour, sullen and unsmiling political hack”.

Trump added that if Republican senators “stay with [McConnell], they will not win again”.

The former president's attack on McConnell is the clearest signal yet that he intends to remain front and centre in Republican party politics.

The legal challenges mounted for Trump on Tuesday, however, after the NAACP, the prominent civil rights organisation, filed a federal lawsuit against him, his attorney Rudy Giuliani and two white supremacist groups for their role in the deadly January 6 siege on the US Capitol.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, meanwhile, said Congress would create an independent, 9/11-style commission to investigate the insurrection. (FT, AP)

Coronavirus digest

  • Joe Biden said the US economy would come “roaring back” if Congress approved his $1.9tn fiscal stimulus plan and that Covid-19 vaccines would be accessible to all Americans who wanted one by the end of July, in an appearance in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

  • Andrew Cuomo, New York governor, is facing the greatest threat to his political career over accusations that his administration tried to cover up the number of Covid-19 deaths among nursing home residents.

  • The EU is set to almost triple its orders of Moderna's coronavirus vaccine as part of an EU push to respond to the emergence of new variants and the possible need for booster shots.

  • Japan has delivered its first dose of Covid-19 vaccine more than two months after inoculations began in the US and UK. Kazuhiro Araki, head of the Tokyo Medical Center, received the jab made by BioNTech and Pfizer on television.

  • British companies, ranging from UK care-home operators to large multinational groups, are looking to draw up “no jab, no job” contracts for employees.

  • Taiwan has accused China of obstructing its efforts to buy coronavirus vaccines from BioNTech. North Korea tried to hack into Pfizer's servers to steal vaccine information, South Korean intelligence officials alleged. (FT, WaPo)

FT photographer Charlie Bibby followed Dr Charlotte Summers, an ICU consultant at the Addenbrooke's Hospital in Cambridge, to record scenes on the frontline of Covid-19 treatment and research. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

In the news

Citigroup loses bid to recover $500m sent to funds in error A US judge ruled that asset managers that received excess payment from Citi, which erroneously sent $500m to creditors of one of its clients instead of the intended $8m, are allowed to keep the payments. Judge Jesse Furman called it “one of the biggest blunders in banking history”. Our corporate finance newsletter Due Diligence has more. (FT)

Berkshire reveals bets on Verizon and Chevron Warren Buffett's conglomerate disclosed multibillion-dollar stakes in telecoms company Verizon and oil and gas major Chevron on Tuesday — investments it had previously kept confidential. (FT)

Ford to sell only electric cars in UK and Europe by 2030 Ford on Wednesday became the largest carmaker so far to pledge all-electric sales by 2030 in the European region. Every passenger car model will have an electric or plug-in hybrid option by 2026, the US carmaker said, and added that it would go 100 per cent electric by the end of the decade. (FT)

New York state sues Amazon over alleged Covid safety breaches New York's attorney-general has sued Amazon over claims it failed to protect its employees adequately during the coronavirus pandemic, days after the ecommerce giant accused Letitia James of overstepping her authority. (FT)

  • Google and Facebook are rushing to agree deals with Australian publishers in a bid to persuade Canberra not to impose world-first rules that would force the tech groups to pay news providers for content.

  • Epic Games has filed a formal antitrust complaint against Apple to the European Commission, the latest shot in an escalating feud between the Fortnite developer and the Silicon Valley giant.

HK stock trading volumes jump to 4 times those of LSE Stock trading volumes in Hong Kong have soared to four times those on London's main exchange as investors, mostly from China, poured about $50bn into shares listed in the Asia finance hub this year amid soaring appetite for technology and health stocks. (FT)

  • The Moscow Exchange is set to open currencies and derivatives trading three hours earlier from March, in the latest effort to drum up more demand from investors in China.

Texas struggles to restore power to millions during Arctic blast Power outages in Texas and across the central US have stretched into a second day, leaving millions facing freezing temperatures without heat or power as an arctic blast disrupted electricity supply and drove demand to records. As our energy team report, the state's energy infrastructure proved no match for the cold blast that veered south from the Arctic Circle. (FT)

Second City comedy group set to be bought by private equity Strauss Zelnick's private equity firm is in advanced talks to buy Second City, the storied comedy group that has launched stars including Tina Fey and the late John Belushi. Zelnick is best known as the chief executive of Take-Two, the video game group behind Grand Theft Auto. (FT)

Marriott chief Arne Sorenson dies The chief executive of the hotel chain died aged 62 at his home in Washington on Monday after a prolonged battle with cancer. (FT)

The day ahead

Nato meeting Defence ministers of the north Atlantic military alliance begin their first meeting since the inauguration of Joe Biden. Missions in Afghanistan and Iraq will be on the agenda. (Nato)

EU virus strain strategy Ursula von der Leyen, European Commission president, is due to unveil plans to prepare for the threat posed by new coronavirus variants. (FT)

Myanmar protests Deposed civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi's remand was set to end on Wednesday, when demonstrations against the military coup are expected, a day after she was handed a second charge. Protesters have accused Beijing of backing the coup. (CNA, Reuters, BBC, FT)

Mario Draghi's policy agenda Italy's new prime minister will address lawmakers for the first time and lay out his economic plans. The Senate will hold a confidence vote later in the day; Draghi is expected to win. (FT)

Earnings round-up Companies reporting earnings include Hilton, Shopify, Baidu and Occidental Petroleum. (FT)

The two-day FT Business of Football summit, exploring how the business of the sport is adapting in challenging times, begins on Wednesday. Sign up here.

What else we're reading

Vaccinating the world is a test of our ability to co-operate What we have learnt from Covid-19, so far, is that the world has shown more co-operation than many might have expected. Even so, given that we are all in this together, it has not been enough, writes Martin Wolf. (FT)

Hedge funds cash in on Reddit rally Retail investors who co-ordinated on Reddit to deal a black eye to hedge funds betting against the price of stocks including GameStop last month also delivered years' worth of gains to a handful of other fund managers. One, Union Square Park Capital Management, gained 12.9 per cent last month. (FT)

China's new digital currency Chinese authorities in several cities have marked the lunar new year with “digital renminbi” red packets, in a trial for a crucial new technology that could lead the world's adoption of digital currencies and set global technical standards. (FT)

Ransomware negotiators Ransomware attacks, in which hackers lock up data or computer systems until they get paid, have been one of the biggest cyber security headaches in the past year. An industry has sprung up in response to help navigate the aftermath of a crippling attack. Meet the people who work to haggle down hackers' demands. (FT)

Tom Peters: McKinsey's work on opioid sales is a new low “My former consultancy demonstrates what is wrong with business school graduates,” writes author Tom Peters. That McKinsey is one of the biggest employers of MBA graduates is not unrelated to the OxyContin affair, he argues. It's led to a consistent short-changing of “moral responsibility of enterprise”. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Starting your debt free journey This week, Claer Barrett hears from a couple in their 30s who have each run up large credit card debts. Chris Browning, presenter of US podcast Popcorn Finance, has practical tips, and debt advice specialist Alan McIntosh explores different solutions. (FT)
